key_points: U.S. Sen. John Thune criticized Republican activists and party leaders for engaging in 'cancel culture' by censuring GOP senators who found former President Donald Trump guilty of inciting an insurrection.
Thune defended fellow Republicans who sided with Democrats, calling it a 'vote of conscience' and warned against shutting out dissenting voices in the party.
He discussed Republicans' priorities under President Joe Biden, the proposed $1.9 trillion coronavirus relief package, and upcoming primary battles within the GOP.
Thune criticized Trump's post-election actions as 'inexcusable' and accused him of undermining the peaceful transfer of power.
Despite his criticism of Trump, Thune voted to acquit him in the impeachment trial, siding with most Republican senators.
Thune suggested taking steps to assist GOP candidates who refrain from discussing conspiracies, praising Rep. Liz Cheney for her performance on most issues.
He believes Republicans are well-positioned to retake the Senate, attributing this to perceived policy overreach by Democrats.
Thune said Biden might govern more moderately without pressure from the progressive wing of the Democratic Party.
The senator predicted Republicans would focus on economic policy, fiscal responsibility, strong borders, and a tough China foreign policy.
Thune expressed reservation about Biden's $1.9 trillion coronavirus package, indicating some Republicans might support a lower amount.
